section.title: Like, would like, be like, look like
section.sectiontitle: Like has different meanings depending on the grammar of the sentence. Like means to enjoy something in general. Use like + -ing for this meaning.
section.text1a: What do you like doing at the weekend?
section.text2a: I like going to the mountains.
section.sectiontitle2: Would like means want something or want to do something. Use would like + infinitive or a noun.
section.text3a: What would you like to do this weekend?
section.text4a: I'd like a quiet night at home and I'd like to see Lord of the Rings on DVD.

section.title: Like, would like, be like, look like
section.sectiontitle: Be like is for asking about character or characteristics. Don't use like in the answer.
section.text1a: A: What is your town like? B: It's quite big and very busy.
section.text2a: A: What is your new car like? B: It's very old.
section.sectiontitle2: Look like is for asking about appearance. Don't use like in the answer.
section.text3a: A: What does your father look like? B: He's tall and he's got black hair.
section.text4a: A: What does his new wife look like? B: She's quite pretty.
